Looks like you're calling `in.nextLine()` twice. Every time you call that, the program reads in another thing from the user.

By default, your code runs in ascending order. However, since you get input twice, you need to enter "N" twice (when it "counts" - i.e. the second time, when you actually use the result) for it to work.

Fixing this is simple: just remove the `in.nextLine()` right before you declare `ascending` and `descending`.

By the way, your user-testing code is a bit more complicated than it needs to be. To set `ascending` correctly, all you need is:

    ascending = in.nextLine().equalsIgnoreCase("y");

It uses [`equalsIgnoreCase()`][1], which is equivalent to your method of getting the first character, uppercasing it, and comparing it to `'Y'`.

This will replace the if/elseif block before your for loop.


  [1]: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/String.html#equalsIgnoreCase(java.lang.String)

Side note #2: you have a whole lot of duplicate code in that for loop. Since the only thing that varies is the condition in the if block, you can just use a boolean expression instead of an inner if/else statement:

        for (int i = 0; i < count; i++) {
            for (int j = 0; j < count - 1; j++) {
                boolean swap = ascending
                        ? array[j] > array[j + 1]
                        : array[j] < array[j + 1];
                if (swap) {
                    int temp = array[j];
                    array[j] = array[j + 1];
                    array[j + 1] = temp;
                }
            }
        }

  [1]: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/String.html#equalsIgnoreCase(java.lang.String)
